statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({4}^{{{x}-{4}}}\right)}+{4}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({4}^{{{x}-{4}}}\right)}+{4} has \displaystyle+{4} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={4}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle{x}-{4}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}={4}. Here \displaystyle{y}={6}.
A second convenient point is one right of 4, which is \displaystyle{x}={5}. Here \displaystyle{y}={12}
